page.title: 04Annual Events in Ripe
page.content: May Day is celebrated in Ripe as it has been for years with maypole dancing. First the children learn the dances and a May Queen is chosen from the older girls by drawing straws, but no one is allowed to be May Queen twice. Then the younger girls draw straws for being attendants. The dresses are brought out from their moth balls. Every girl makes her own posy and they all meet at the village centre. The May Queen and her retinue are ensconced in horse drawn carts and the proccession wends its way from the Lamb Inn down Ripe Street round the finger post to the garden where the dancing takes place. The may pole is decked with coloured ribbons and the girls dance round and weave the ribbons. Teas are served and stall selling cakes and crafts help to make money for repairs to the church.
